instructions: You have multiple commits that have yet to be pushed to the remote repo. Try to squash them all into a single commit using the git rebase -i command before pushing. (only make multiple commits in scenarios that require it)
Use git blame to find who last modified a specific line in a file.

You’ve made some changes to the working directory, but you forgot to switch from main to a feature branch. Create and switch to the new branch using git branch and git switch, and carry over the changes (try to do it with the git stash command).

You’ve made some changes to the working directory, but you forgot to switch from main to a feature branch. Create and switch to the new branch using git branch and git switch, and carry over the changes (try to do it without the stash command).
Merge your feature branch with main within your text editor using the git merge command and push from main.
Merge your feature branch with main within your text editor using the git rebase command and push from main.
Merge your feature branch with main on Github using the rebase option.
Merge your feature branch with main on Github using other merge styles.
Compare your feature branch with main using the git diff command.
You have multiple commits that have yet to be pushed to the remote repo. Try to revert to your second most recent commit using the git reset command before pushing.
You have multiple commits that have yet to be pushed to the remote repo. Try to revert to your second most recent commit using the git revert command before pushing.
You have a few unstaged changes in your working directory, add them to your previous commit before pushing.
You have a few unstaged changes in your working directory, get rid of them using the git restore command before pushing.
Merge the latest version of main into your feature branch so you can deal with merge conflicts in your text editor before pushing.
Use git log --graph to visualize commit history with branches.

You’ve made a commit to your local repo, but you forgot to switch from main to a feature branch. Create and switch to the new branch using git branch, and then use git reset to remove the commit from main.
You’ve staged some new changes, but you forgot to switch from main to a feature branch. Create and switch to the new branch using git branch and git switch, and carry over the changes.
You have a few staged changes in your working directory, get rid of them using the git restore command before pushing.

You’ve created a branch to work on a new feature, but you forgot to actually switch to it before making your commits. Switch to the new branch using git switch, and use git cherry-pick to move over your latest commits. You should also use git reset to remove the commits from main.
